content.text: Physical security might seem less relevant for a remote team, but it's actually just as important. Your home office is now part of ClearTriage's security perimeter, and a few simple practices go a long way toward maintaining FedRAMP compliance.
Your computer screen is a window into ClearTriage's systems. Protecting it is one of the easiest and most effective security measures you can take.

items: **Lock your screen whenever you step away** - Yes, even at home. It takes one keystroke (Windows+L or Cmd+Control+Q) and prevents family members, visitors, or service workers from accidentally (or intentionally) accessing sensitive data.
**Position your screen thoughtfully** - Avoid having your back to windows or high-traffic areas where others might see sensitive information.
**Use privacy screens if needed** - If you work in shared spaces or travel frequently, consider a privacy filter for your laptop.

content.text: Make screen locking a reflex. Every time you stand up, lock your screen. It's like putting on your seatbelt - a small action that becomes automatic and provides significant protection.
Even in our digital world, physical documents still exist and need proper handling.

items: **Secure any printed sensitive documents** - If you must print something containing patient data or system information, treat it like cash. Keep it in sight or locked away.
**Proper disposal is critical** - Any document containing sensitive information must be shredded, not just thrown away. This includes draft documents, old notes, or even Post-its with passwords.
**Minimize printing** - The best way to secure physical documents is to not create them in the first place. Question whether printing is truly necessary.

content.text: Your regular trash becomes public domain once it hits the curb. Always shred sensitive documents - a $30 cross-cut shredder is a worthwhile investment for your home office.

content.title: What Counts as Sensitive?
content.content: You printed out some AWS configuration details for reference during a call. Even though it doesn't contain patient data, it reveals information about our infrastructure. This document needs to be shredded when you're done, not tossed in the recycling bin.

content.text: Remember, physical security is about building good habits. Since we're all working from home, we're each responsible for maintaining the physical security of our own workspace. The practices above aren't burdensome - they're simple actions that protect both ClearTriage and the veterans' data we help safeguard.
